author: mklement0
body:
Note:

* Changing this behavior, which goes back to Windows PowerShell, would technically be a breaking change; the question is whether it falls into [bucket 3: Unlikely Grey Area](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/dev-process/breaking-change-contract.md#bucket-3-unlikely-grey-area)

* If a change isn't possible, the behavior should be documented (which should happen for _older_ versions either way).

---

When PowerShell breaks multiline text into a stream / array of individual lines with `Get-Content`, it considers a terminal trailing newline an _optional terminator_; that is, if the _last_ line has a trailing newline, _no_ additional line is reported.

By contrast, `Get-Clipboard` _does_ report an extra, empty line, which, however, is consistent with what manual splitting with `-split '\r?\n` would return.

Aligning `Get-Clipboard`'s behavior with that of `Get-Content` makes more sense to me, however, given that:

* Text copied from Excel has such trailing newlines, which you wouldn't want to reported with an extra empty string.

* Having manually selected and copied lines in a text file may situationally include or not include a trailing newline, and it is unlikely that the user intended the difference to be meaningful.

## Steps to reproduce

On macOS (but the behavior applies to all platforms; use `xclip -selection clipboard` instead of `pbcopy` on Linux):

```powershell
sh -c 'printf ''line 1\nline 2\n'' | pbcopy'; Get-Clipboard | Should -Be 'line 1', 'line 2'
```

## Expected behavior

The test should succeed.

## Actual behavior

The test fails, because an extra, empty string is output:

```none
Expected @('line 1', 'line 2'), but got @('line 1', 'line 2', <empty>)
```

## Environment data

```none
PowerShell Core 7.2.0-preview.3
```
title: Get-Clipboard outputs an extra empty string if the clipboard text has a trailing newline
